Content: Which of Mrs. Snavin's actions helps the reader visualize why Jake is embarrassed?

A.Choice: Mrs. Snavin was my third-grade teacher, and she acted like computers were scary, especially the new ones.

Key.Rationale: It tells how Mrs. Snavin acts when using computers.

B.Choice: She was confused about a program we were supposed to use for a math project.

Key.Rationale: It tells why Mrs. Snavin is confused.

C.Choice: Then she shook her head and let out this big sigh.

Key.Rationale: It helps the reader visualize Mrs. Snavin's frustration.

D.Choice: She said it so loud that every kid in the classroom stopped and turned to look at us, just in time to see Mrs. Snavin pat me on the top of my head like I was a nice little poodle or something.

Key.Rationale: It helps the reader visualize why Jake is embarrassed.

Content: Paragraph 6 is important to the development of the plot because it is where —

Key.Rationale: Jake does not learn a lesson in paragraph 6.
Jake's problem begins when Mrs. Snavin praises him in paragraph 6.
Jake does not have to make a decision in paragraph 6.
Jake's problem is not solved in paragraph 6.

Content: Jake's interaction with his teacher shows that he —

Key.Rationale: Jake turns red when his classmates stare.
Jake likes computers.

C.Choice: wants to be Mrs. Snavin's favorite student

Key.Rationale: This information is not in the story.

D.Choice: wants Mrs. Snavin to help him with his math project

Key.Rationale: Jake does not want help with his project.

Content: What does Jake learn in this story?

F.Choice: Taking a risk is more important than making a mistake.

Key.Rationale: Jake does not take a risk.

G.Choice: Offer help to people whenever they clearly need it.

Key.Rationale: Jake does not learn that he should help others.

H.Choice: People often know more than they think they do.

Key.Rationale: Jake does not learn about what other people know.

J.Choice: Being helpful can bring unexpected results.

Key.Rationale: Jake does not know that helping will cause an embarrassing situation.

Content: Read paragraph 8 from the story.
:box:So I mumbled something like, “Oh, it was nothing.” Which was a mistake.
Why does Jake think he's made a mistake?

A.Choice: Mrs. Snavin continues to praise him in front of the class.

Key.Rationale: Jake's response causes Mrs. Snavin to praise him more.

B.Choice: Mrs. Snavin is unable to get the computer program to open.

Key.Rationale: Jake's response does not cause Mrs. Snavin to have problems with the program.

C.Choice: The class is over before he has time to work on the math project.

Key.Rationale: Jake's response does not keep him from working on his project.

D.Choice: The librarian comes to help the students with their work.

Key.Rationale: Jake's response does not cause the librarian to help.

Content: What does Jake mean when he says he is “saved by the bell”?

F.Choice: Jake can now leave the awkward situation behind.

Key.Rationale: This means that Jake can now leave the classroom.

G.Choice: Jake can finally go to his favorite class of the school day.

Key.Rationale: This does not mean that Jake is going to his favorite class.

H.Choice: Jake is tired of trying to help make the computer work.

Key.Rationale: Jake easily makes the computer work.

J.Choice: Jake is certain his classmates will forget what they saw.

Key.Rationale: This does not mean that Jake's classmates will forget.

Content: What is the best summary of the story?

A.Choice: Jake enjoys working with computers, so his teacher Mrs. Snavin tells the students in the class to ask Jake when they need help using their computer.

Key.Rationale: It focuses only on the class asking Jake for help.

B.Choice: Jake helps Mrs. Snavin use the computer. When Mrs. Snavin announces that Jake has helped her, he worries what the other students are thinking.

Key.Rationale: It focuses on the most important ideas in the story.

C.Choice: Mrs. Snavin is used to asking for help with the classroom computer, but she discovers that one of her students knows a lot about computers.

Key.Rationale: It focuses only on Mrs. Snavin's discovery.

D.Choice: Mrs. Snavin wants her students to use the new computers in their classroom, but she is having trouble getting the computers to work.

Key.Rationale: It focuses only on Mrs. Snavin's problem.

Content: As it is used in paragraph 9, the word e͟x͟p͟e͟r͟t means a person who —

Key.Rationale: An expert is someone who is highly skilled, and Mrs. Snavin thinks Jake is very skilled with computers.
An expert is not the same as a helper.
An expert is not necessarily a person who enjoys working on machines.
An expert is not necessarily a person who has learned from watching others.

Content: Which sentence best states the main idea of the selection?

A.Choice: All this information was available because of the microchip that had been placed under Scrub's skin many years earlier.

Key.Rationale: It is a detail about Scrub.

B.Choice: Microchips have helped thousands of owners get their lost pets back.

Key.Rationale: It tells what the entire selection is mainly about.

C.Choice: However, thanks to her microchip, Roxy was soon returned to her grateful owner.

Key.Rationale: It is a detail about Roxy.

D.Choice: However, tags and collars can fall off or become difficult to read.

Key.Rationale: It is a detail about tags and collars.

Content: The diagram of a microchip is included to show —

F.Choice: a detailed view of a microchip

Key.Rationale: The diagram shows an enlarged, detailed view of a microchip.
The diagram does not show a scanner.
The diagram does not show where to put a microchip.

J.Choice: the differences between pet collars and microchips

Key.Rationale: The diagram does not show differences between pet collars and microchips.

Content: Why is it surprising that Roxy was found?

A.Choice: Roxy had wandered away from her owner.

Key.Rationale: The fact that Roxy wandered away is not why it is surprising that she was found.

B.Choice: Roxy was lost for several years.

Key.Rationale: Paragraph 4 tells that Roxy was missing for months, not years.

C.Choice: Roxy was on a busy street.

Key.Rationale: The fact that Roxy was on a busy street is not why it is surprising that she was found.
The fact that Roxy was far from home makes it surprising that she was found.

Content: The purpose of the questions in paragraph 2 is to —

F.Choice: interest readers in learning how microchips help reunite owners with lost pets

Key.Rationale: The questions make readers curious about how microchips reunite owners and pets.

G.Choice: tell readers about the services available at the animal shelter

Key.Rationale: The questions do not tell readers about services at the animal shelter.

H.Choice: give readers details about what is happening in the photograph of Scrub

Key.Rationale: The questions do not give readers details about the photograph of Scrub.

J.Choice: share with readers how it feels to lose a pet

Key.Rationale: The questions do not share with readers how it feels to lose a pet.

Content: To learn when pets can be microchipped, the reader should refer to the —

Key.Rationale: The diagram does not show when pets can be microchipped.

B.Choice: caption under the photograph after paragraph 3

Key.Rationale: The caption does not tell when pets can be microchipped.
The photographs do not show when pets can be microchipped.
The boxed information tells that pets can be microchipped when they are 6 to 8 weeks old.

Content: Look at the diagram below.
problems/TX17G3R/media/14a.jpg
Which of these completes the diagram?

F.Choice: Why It Was Difficult for George's Owners to Find Him

Key.Rationale: The diagram's details do not tell why it was difficult to find George.

G.Choice: How George's Owners Were Able to Locate Him

Key.Rationale: The diagram's details do not tell how George was found.

H.Choice: What George's Owners Did to Try to Find Him

Key.Rationale: The diagram's details tell what George's owners did to try to find him.

J.Choice: Where George's Owners Eventually Found Him

Key.Rationale: The diagram's details do not tell where George's owners found him.

Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 2.
:box:Once the chip is in place, the pet does not feel it anymore.
This sentence helps the reader infer —

Key.Rationale: The sentence does not help the reader infer where microchips are located.

B.Choice: that microchips do not bother pets

Key.Rationale: The sentence helps the reader infer that microchips do not bother pets.
The sentence does not help the reader infer how microchips are inserted.

D.Choice: that microchips are helpful for pets

Key.Rationale: The sentence does not help the reader infer that microchips are helpful for pets.

Content: In paragraph 6, the word p͟e͟r͟m͟i͟t͟t͟e͟d means —

Key.Rationale: The context indicates that the hotel allowed Mrs. Baird to pay in bread and rolls.
The context does not indicate that the hotel begged Mrs. Baird to pay in bread and rolls.
The context does not indicate that the hotel forced Mrs. Baird to pay in bread and rolls.
The context does not indicate that the hotel needed Mrs. Baird to pay in bread and rolls.

Content: How did Mrs. Baird begin selling baked goods?

A.Choice: She went to work for a bakery.

Key.Rationale: Mrs. Baird did not begin selling baked goods at a bakery.

B.Choice: She agreed to bake rolls for a hotel.

Key.Rationale: Mrs. Baird did not begin selling baked goods at a hotel.

C.Choice: Her neighbors paid her for her bread.

Key.Rationale: Mrs. Baird gave baked goods to her neighbors.

D.Choice: Her husband sold them in his restaurant.

Key.Rationale: Paragraph 2 tells that Mrs. Baird started selling baked goods at her husband's restaurant.

Content: The subheadings in the selection support the main idea that Mrs. Baird —

F.Choice: turned a small business into a large one

Key.Rationale: The subheadings tell that the business began as a family business and grew over time.

G.Choice: was proud of the baked goods she made

Key.Rationale: The subheadings do not tell how Mrs. Baird felt about her baked goods.

H.Choice: was pleased that her family helped her

Key.Rationale: The subheadings do not tell that Mrs. Baird was pleased that her family helped her.

J.Choice: wanted everyone to have enough bread

Key.Rationale: The subheadings do not tell that Mrs. Baird wanted people to have enough bread.

Content: Mrs. Baird purchased an oven because the wood-burning stove she was using —

Key.Rationale: Because paragraph 4 states that the wood-burning stove belonged to Mrs. Baird.
Because the wood- burning stove could bake only a few loaves at a time, but the oven could bake 40 loaves at a time.
There is no evidence that the wood- burning stove burned the bread.
There is no evidence that Mrs. Baird's wood-burning stove cooked too slowly.

Content: Which statement describes one of Mrs. Baird's business challenges?

F.Choice: She had trouble teaching her children how to help with the business.

Key.Rationale: There is no evidence that Mrs. Baird had trouble teaching her children how to help.

G.Choice: She needed to find new ways to deliver her baked goods as sales increased.

Key.Rationale: The selection tells that Mrs. Baird's sons had to keep changing delivery methods to handle increasing sales.

H.Choice: She was not able to remember the type of baked goods her customers ordered.

Key.Rationale: There is no evidence that Mrs. Baird was unable to remember her customers' orders.

J.Choice: She was not able to make enough money to purchase supplies.

Key.Rationale: There is no evidence that Mrs. Baird was unable to make enough money.

Content: What is the theme of the selection?

A.Choice: Hard work often leads to success.

Key.Rationale: The Bairds' hard work led to success, and this message is found throughout the selection.

B.Choice: Some people work more than others.

Key.Rationale: There is no one in the selection who worked more than others.

C.Choice: Popular items often change through the years.

Key.Rationale: There is no indication that Mrs. Baird changed her recipe over the years.

D.Choice: No one knows what to expect in the future.

Key.Rationale: There is nothing stated in the selection about knowing what the future will bring.

Content: The author included the section titled “A Family Affair” to describe how Mrs. Baird's children —

Key.Rationale: The section includes nothing about how the children liked the bread.

G.Choice: helped her in the bread business

Key.Rationale: The section gives examples of how Mrs. Baird's children helped when they were older.
The section does not describe how the children learned to bake bread.

J.Choice: encouraged people to buy her bread

Key.Rationale: The section does not describe how the children encouraged people to buy their mother's bread.

Content: Read this dictionary entry.

:box:sign \'sīn\ noun
1. a movement that shows a thought or command
2. in math, language, or music, a mark that stands for a certain idea
3. evidence that a fact or idea is true
4. a display that advertises or gives the name of a business
Which meaning of the word s͟i͟g͟n is used in paragraph 8?

Key.Rationale: In paragraph 8, sign does not mean a movement that shows a thought or command.
In paragraph 8, sign does not mean a mark in math, language, or music.
In paragraph 8, sign does not mean evidence that a fact or idea is true.
In paragraph 8, sign means a display that advertises or gives the name of a business.

Content: At first, Mrs. Baird's sons delivered her bread —

Key.Rationale: Mrs. Baird's sons first delivered bread by walking to customers' homes.
The sons delivered by car after delivering by foot, wagon, and bicycle.
The sons delivered by bicycle after delivering by foot.
The sons delivered by wagon after delivering by foot and bicycle.

Content: One likely reason Mrs. Baird became a successful business owner is that —

A.Choice: her business allowed her to spend time with her children

Key.Rationale: There is no evidence that the time Mrs. Baird spent with her children led to her success.

B.Choice: she did not want people to have to make their own bread

Key.Rationale: The selection does not tell how Mrs. Baird felt about other people making their own bread.

C.Choice: she did not want to work in a restaurant like her husband

Key.Rationale: There is no evidence that Mrs. Baird did not want to work in a restaurant.

D.Choice: her business involved something that she enjoyed doing

Key.Rationale: Paragraph 1 tells that Mrs. Baird loved baking bread, and this is likely a reason for her success.

Content: The caption under the first photograph in the selection explains —

Key.Rationale: The caption does not tell where the photograph was taken.
The caption does not explain why the photograph was taken.
The caption does not tell the age of the photograph.
The caption gives the name of the person in the photograph.

Content: The author wrote this selection most likely to —

A.Choice: describe what a teddy bear looks like

Key.Rationale: The description of the teddy bear is only a small part of the selection.

B.Choice: encourage the reader to buy a teddy bear

Key.Rationale: The author is not trying to get the reader to buy a teddy bear.

C.Choice: inform the reader about the history of teddy bears

Key.Rationale: The author informs the reader of the history of teddy bears from the early 1900s to today.

D.Choice: tell the reader about a president who liked teddy bears

Key.Rationale: The author gives little information about President Theodore Roosevelt.

Content: What does the word c͟r͟a͟z͟e mean in paragraph 3?

Key.Rationale: Craze does not mean purpose, and there are no clues to support that option.
Craze means popularity, and there are several examples in paragraph 3 that support this.
Craze does not mean changes, and there are no clues to suggest that teddy bears were changing.
Craze does not mean materials, and there are no clues to support that option.

Content: The reader can tell from the selection that nurses may use teddy bears to —

A.Choice: encourage children to stay in bed when they are sick

Key.Rationale: There is no evidence that nurses use teddy bears to get sick children to stay in bed.

B.Choice: keep children busy while they are waiting to see the doctor

Key.Rationale: There is no evidence that nurses use teddy bears to keep children busy while they are waiting to see the doctor.

C.Choice: give children a toy to play with when they stay in a hospital

Key.Rationale: There is no evidence that nurses use teddy bears to give hospitalized children something to play with.

D.Choice: provide a fun way to teach children about health and medicine

Key.Rationale: Paragraph 4 states that nurses use teddy bears to teach children about health and doctor visits.

Content: What does paragraph 1 help the reader understand about the first teddy bear?

F.Choice: How big the first teddy bear was

Key.Rationale: Paragraph 1 has no information about the size of the first teddy bear.

G.Choice: How the first teddy bear got its name

Key.Rationale: Paragraph 1 explains that the first teddy bear was named after Roosevelt.

H.Choice: How much the first teddy bear cost

Key.Rationale: Paragraph 1 does not tell how much the first teddy bear cost.

J.Choice: How long it took to sew the first teddy bear

Key.Rationale: Paragraph 1 does not tell how long it took to sew the first teddy bear.

Content: Read the diagram below.
problems/TX17G3R/media/31a.jpg
Which sentence best completes the diagram?

A.Choice: Breeze lived in a national park.

Key.Rationale: The fact that Breeze lived in a national park did not cause horse-farm workers to care for Breeze.
The fact that Breeze grew strong did not cause horse-farm workers to care for Breeze.

C.Choice: Breeze was separated from his mother.

Key.Rationale: The fact that Breeze was separated from his mother caused horse- farm workers to care for Breeze.
The fact that Breeze cuddled with Buttons did not cause horse- farm workers to care for Breeze.

Content: What is the best summary of the section titled “Popular Toys”?

F.Choice: Many toy companies started making teddy bears. Everyone wanted their own teddy bear. Children everywhere held their teddy bears while sleeping. They also enjoyed having their picture taken with their toy bears and reading to their teddy bears.

Key.Rationale: It describes only part of the section.

G.Choice: Everyone loved the teddy bears. They were so popular that other toy companies started making their own teddy bears. While they were wanted by everyone, children were especially fond of the teddy bears. Parents often bought teddy bears for their children.

Key.Rationale: It describes only part of the section.

H.Choice: At one time everyone wanted to have a teddy bear. Children played with them. Soon writers were writing songs and stories about them. Children enjoyed reading the books about teddy bears. They also sang songs about teddy bears.

Key.Rationale: It describes only part of the section.

J.Choice: Teddy bears quickly became a popular toy, and several toy companies started making their own teddy bears. Children wanted to play and snuggle with the bears. Songs and stories were written about the bears. Soon they were seen on all sorts of items, including books and clothing.

Key.Rationale: It tells the most important ideas in the entire section.

Content: In paragraph 1, the word h͟o͟n͟o͟r means to —

Key.Rationale: The word honor does not mean copy, and there is no evidence that the Michtoms made the bear to copy the president.
The word honor does not mean help, and there is no evidence that the Michtoms made the bear to help the president.
The word honor does not mean make fun of, and there is no evidence that the Michtoms wanted to make fun of the president.
The word honor means show respect to in paragraph 1, and there is context to suggest that the Michtoms respected the president.

Content: Details in the selection support the idea that teddy bears —

F.Choice: help animals more than they help children

Key.Rationale: There is no evidence that teddy bears help animals more than they help children.

G.Choice: are still loved by children today

Key.Rationale: The selection gives examples in paragraphs 3, 4, and 6 of how teddy bears are still loved by children today.

H.Choice: are no longer the subject of books

Key.Rationale: There is no evidence that books are no longer written about teddy bears.

J.Choice: have become less useful over time

Key.Rationale: There is no evidence that teddy bears have become less useful over time.
